0.user_question: Artie has a flower stand at the Farmers Market. He sells three kinds of flowers: marigolds, petunias and begonias. He usually sells marigolds for $2.74 per pot, petunias for $1.87 per pot and begonias for $2.12 per pot. Artie has no change today, so he has decided to round all his prices to the nearest dollar. If Artie sells 12 pots of marigolds, 4719835 pots of petunias and 17 pots of begonias, how much will he make?

1.subquestion: How much would one unit (pot) be rounded off from their respective initial price?

subanswer.text: Marigolds go upwards because they cost $2.74; hence its units get changed overto $3 per pot. Petunia’s gets decreased since these sell for $1.87, thus getting downgraded to $1 per pot. Begonia also increases due to being sold out for $2.12; therefore changing to $2 per pot. The answers are $3, $1, and $2 respectively.

2.subquestion: Now we can calculate if we know everything else about arties sales...

subanswer.text: Rounding the price of marigolds ($2.74) to the nearest dollar would make it $3 because when you look up towards or past $.50 ,you always go backward (round down), but here since its .74 which goes over (.50)we want our estimate rounded UP!

ost_step.1: Let us find each category separately then add them together.. For example…for marigolds we multiply their count(i.e., number of items purchased/bought)×price=$3 ×$12= ...........and repeat this procedure till every item bought using correct formulas before adding those values altogether once computed.(This way one can determine exact sum value that customer needs without any discrepancies). Step 5 : Total money made from Selling Marigolds+Total Money Made From Selling Begonias+$Made By Sales Of PETUNIA_PLUS=(SellingsPriceOfMarigoldPot*Numberofpottedmarigolds)+($Selling PriceperBegoniapot * Numberoffbegoniapots)= $(3x12)+($(2)(17))=$(36)+$(34)=$70.........since u only know about sales numbers not sure if everyone buys wholenumber quantity eg:(if someone wants half dozen ..do i charge him full six plus extra quarter?)but yes knowing amounts wont matter cause math helps solve problems like yours!(not just guesses!)

direct_answer.text:
Firstly let's calculate revenue generated through sale of marigolds which cost Rs. (3 times 12):

Revenue from marigolds = price per unit * units sold
                              =  2.74 * 12
                              ≈    ₹32.88 ~ rounded off to ₹33 as it was mentioned to sell amount nearest whole integer.
So Revenue from Marshigolds=₹33
Now calculating earnings earned due to Petunias’ purchases; since its specified below single digit figures , therefore multiplying respective digits . Thus ;
Earnings upon purchase of petunias (Rs.) = Single Digit Multiplication Table [From Second Column ][Row No] -> First Cell Value represents Summation Resultant Figures => Earning Due To Each Unit Sold @ Rs.= 1st Row:: Col No.[Second Column]; thus Earnings Perpetually Upon Procurement-> 2nd row col no:[2nd column], hence result shows multiplication product yielding output equal or less than original input figure ie.; 'one'. 0.user_question: Artie has a flower stand at the Farmers Market. He sells three kinds of flowers: marigolds, petunias and begonias. He usually sells marigolds for $2.74 per pot, petunias for $1.87 per pot and begonias for $2.12 per pot. Artie has no change today, so he has decided to round all his prices to the nearest dollar. If Artie sells 12 pots of marigolds, 4719835 pots of petunias and 17 pots of begonias, how much will he make?

ost_step.1: Round each price to the nearest whole number: Marigolds become $3/pot; Petunias remain unchanged as their price rounded off would result in zero ($1.87) which doesn't contribute profitably; Begonias becomes $2/pot (since we don't consider cents when it comes to currency).

direct_answer.text:
Let's break this down into steps considering our hint:
Marigold Price Rounding -> Original Price :Rounded Off | Total Pots Sold|Total Sales Amount  
$2.74 ->              $3             |         12            |     12*3=$36   
Petunias                $1.87->         $2           |        N/A               |       Not profitable                    
Begonia Prices          $2.12->          $2           |         17            |     17*2=$34
Now let's sum up these totals => 
Sum of sales amount = Summation(each row 'total sale')= $36+$Not Profitable+$34
As said before since Petunia was not profitable its value cancels out while adding hence,$36+$-34 equals to $2 . Hence , Arty makes $2 overall.

Artie has a flower stand at the Farmers Market. He sells three kinds of flowers: marigolds, petunias and begonias. He usually sells marigolds for $2.74 per pot, petunias for $1.87 per pot and begonias for $2.12 per pot. Artie has no change today, so he has decided to round all his prices to the nearest dollar. If Artie sells 12 pots of marigolds, 4719835 pots of petunias and 17 pots of begonias, how much will he make?

direct_answer.text: First, let's find out the rounded price for each type of flower. Marigolds cost approximately $3 (since we round up because $2.74 is closer to $3 than it is to $2), petunias would still cost about $2 (rounding down since $1.87 is less than halfway toward $2), and begonias also come close to $2 when rounded. Next, multiply these rounded prices by their respective quantities sold. That means artie makes 12*$3=<<12*3=36>>36 from marigolds, 4719835*$2=$ <<4719835*2=9439670>>9439670 from petunias, and finally 17*$2 =$<<17*2=34>>34 from begonias. Add them together ($36+$9439670+$34) which equals to $(9439740). Hence, if Artie rounds his sales as planned, he will earn around $9439740 during this farmers market run. The

0.user_question: Artie has a flower stand at the Farmers Market. He sells three kinds of flowers: marigolds, petunias and begonias. He usually sells marigolds for $2.74 per pot, petunias for $1.87 per pot and begonias for $2.12 per pot. Artie has no change today, so he has decided to round all his prices to the nearest dollar. If Artie sells 12 pots of marigolds, 4719835 pots of petunias and 17 pots of begonias, how much will he make?

ost_step.1: Round each price to the nearest whole number: Marigolds become $3/pot; Petunias remain unchanged as their price rounded off would result in zero ($1.87) which doesn't contribute profitably; Begonias becomes $2/pot (since we don't consider cents when it comes to currency).

direct_answer.text:
Let's break this down into steps considering our hint:
Marigold Price Rounding -> Original Price :Rounded Off | Total Pots Sold|Total Sales Amount  
$2.74 ->              $3             |         12            |     12*3=$36   
Petunias                $1.87->         $2           |        N/A               |       Not profitable                    
Begonia Prices          $2.12->          $2           |         17            |     17*2=$34
Now let's sum up these totals => 
Sum of sales amount = Summation(each row 'total sale')= $36+$Not Profitable+$34
As said before since Petunia was not profitable its value cancels out while adding hence,$36+$-34 equals to $2 . Hence , Arty makes $2 overall.
